comment.narrative: - Inexistence de mécanismes de communication sur le COVID-19.

- Au moins 100 Licences Zoom sont acquises en faveur du gouvernement pour faciliter la communication dans la prise de décision. - Existence d'une solution numérique utilisant les nouvelles technologies pour lutter contre la pandémie Covid-19 - Au moins 2 000 ménages sont assistées par les moyens de subsistance et d'hygiènes - Au moins 200 PME sont soutenus pour remettre sur pied leur activités

- 101 Licences ZOOM ont permis à 6 Ministères membre de la coordination de la riposte COVID-19 de travailler en respectant les mesures barrières et produite les résultats attendus et vital dans la riposte. Ainsi via ce système de communication le gouvernement a pu informer les population sur l'évolution de la situation du COVID-19 au Congo.

description.narrative: 1. Number of cases reported and tracked between April and September 2020 2. raising exercises, nationally and in their constituencies; number of MPs supported to create platforms for effective communication with constituents

comment.narrative: 1. Referral Pathway developed with limited implementation 2. 4 out of 111 MPs discuss or mention risk of increased incidents of GBV within the COVID_19 outbreak; 75 out of 111 MPs maintain effective platforms for effective communication with constituents

Activity 1: Operation support to Femili PNG and police officers working on the frontline to expand their scope of work to follow up and monitor the localities with high incidents of crime and GBV cases
Target: At least 60 percent of cases reported are referred to safe houses and are tracked
Activity 2: Support members of parliament to deliver correct and effective messages on GBV prevention within the COVID-19 outbreak
Target: At least 50 percent of MPs deliver correct and effective messages on GBV prevention within the COVID-19 outbreak
Activity 3: Provide platform for citizens to bring issues and needs to the attention of their political representatives and for their representative to respond to concerns
Target: At least 50 percent of MPs are able to provide citizens with platforms to respond to concerns

Activity 1 Target: At least 60 percent of cases reported are referred to safe houses and are tracked
Result: The RPNGC is still yet to establish the information management system. Once establish the percent of clients referred to safe houses can be tracked. However, with the engagement of Femili PNG as the implementing partner in strengthening safe houses FPNG was able to provide assistance to over 432 (Female Adults = 302, Female Child = 27, Male Adults = 16, Male Child = 15 and Child Dependents accompanying Female adults to safe accommodation = 72) Female survivors of FSV and individuals. About 40 percent of the survivors assisted were people living with disabilities (Female Adults = 14 percent, Female Child = 7 percent and Male Adults = 19 percent). Furthermore, food, utilities, hygiene and other necessity support was also provided to 83 percent of Female Adults, 14 percent of Female Child and 3 percent Male Child; including provision of emergency assistance to 94 percent of Female Adults, 4 percent of Female Child and 2 percent of Male Child. A total of 584 World Health Organization posters and 3550 National Department of Health posters on COVID were also distributed between July and October 2020.
Activity 2 Target: At least 50 percent of MPs deliver correct and effective messages on GBV prevention within the COVID-19 outbreak
Result: A parliamentary committee on the coalition against GBV was formed and signed by 20 members of parliament. This is 18 percent of the targeted 50 percent. They have been greatly supported by their spouses with Mrs. Marape leading the mobilzation of the spouses. Mrs. Toroama, the wife of president Toroama is also involved.
Activity 3 Target: At least 50 percent of MPs are able to provide citizens with platforms to respond to concerns Result: This is the same as above and will continue to be monitored over the cause of 2021

description.narrative: The aim is to rapidly enable a cash transfer mechanism for those at risk by covid-19

sector.narrative: Accelerate structural transformations

description.narrative: 600,000 poor households access to national cash transfer programme during the Covid-19 pandemic

comment.narrative: On-Demand Identification of Poor Households registration

A total of 674,146 households affected by COVID-19 are now able to access cash transfers from the Government. The rapid implementation of this cash transfer programme was facilitated by UNDP’s mobilization of funding from Australia to provide 1,700 tablets and software to the Ministry of Planning along with training for rapid and accurate registration of citizens into Cambodia’s social protection identification system [On Demand Identification of Poor Households (OD-ID Poor)]. This has progressed digitalization of the system and served as the basis to reach the extreme poor and vulnerable. The rapid implementation of the cash transfer program has also been a remarkable success for showing Government capacity at central and subnational levels. It has given rise to a fundamental shift in many parts of Government to a deeper and more positive appreciation of social protection.

description.narrative: COVID Rapid Res through Provision of Personal Protective Equipment and improved Radio Communication

sector.narrative: Build resilience to shocks and crisis

description.narrative: Frontline health workers are better protected against Covid-19

comment.narrative: Support provincial governments in better management of COVID-19 response

Nepal’s health workers are now better protected against COVID-19 and prepared to manage the outbreak through direct support from the UNDP Nepal CO and Field Offices. In total, over 165,000 surgical and cloth masks have been provided to frontline responders through local governments. A new Polymerase Chain Reaction (PCR) testing machine, with the capacity of analysing more than 200 tests per day was installed in Lumbini Provincial Hospital of Province 5. The public awareness of COVID-19, immediate protection measures, and short-term response and recovery efforts has been significantly enhanced. In total, over 3 million people have been reached through radio, public service announcements (PSAs) and social media, in an effort to assist in resolving health, social and economic issues during the crisis. More than 1,500 people also received direct support through call-in radio programmes, with 30 per cent of issues resolved. Some examples included ensuring that immediate relief support reached the most vulnerable groups, connecting farmers with buyers, and providing medical advice to pregnant mothers. With support from UNDP, UNFPA and UN Women, The Association of Community Radio Broadcasters (ACORAB) and its Community Information Network (CIN), hosted the popular radio show ‘Jeevan Rakshya’ to ensure continued connectivity and access to relevant authorities and support services, despite mobility restrictions during the nation-wide lockdown.

description.narrative: Conduct socio-economic and livelihoods impact assessments focusing on vulnerable population

sector.narrative: Build resilience to shocks and crisis

comment.narrative: Conduct livelihood impact assessments by Covid-19

In early March, with just a handful of positive cases in Nepal but with strict lockdown measures, UNDP was one of the first organizations to initiate a rapid socio-economic assessment in Nepal to gauge the impact of the crisis particularly on the most vulnerable demographics. UNDP commissioned this rapid assessment which was based on phone surveys of 700 businesses and 400 individuals, and consultations with over 30 private sector organizations and government agencies. The assessment provided the first glimpses into the unfolding disruptions in the economy and the lives of the most vulnerable. The report illustrated the way the crisis was threatening the survival of formal and informal MSMEs and the livelihoods of informal workers, women from lower income households putting at risk the most vulnerable of falling further into poverty through widespread of income and jobs. The rapid assessment recommended three policy takeaways. First, to guard against vulnerabilities including those induced by climate by strengthening social protection, building climate resilient infrastructure and sustaining livelihoods. Second, to orient Nepal’s pattern of public finances to augment human capabilities to safeguard development gains and build economic resilience. And third, to introduce measures to save bankruptcies of firms and foster new sources of job creating growth and self-reliance. These early findings commissioned by UNDP was shared with UNCT agencies, the government and development partners and meaningfully informed the planning of response and recovery initiatives.
In addition, the Rapid Assessment of the Effect of COVID-19 Pandemic on the Economy of Gandaki Province was conducted in UNDP’s support. The findings of the assessment have been utilized by the Province Government in Gandaki to inform its macro-economic forecasting and sectoral impacts.

Assistance will be provided with the delivery of social programmes that include the National Employment Programme (NEP); The 70 non-contributory pensions; the Rapid Response Agency; the Public Assistance Programme and stabilization measures in support of educational institutions and tertiary education. These programmes benefit over 10% of the Dominica population and target vulnerable groups, single parents, women and at-risk youth, indigenous populations and the elderly.

comment.narrative: Indicator 3.1.2.1: Number of government entities supported to ensure business continuity and provision of basic and social services during the COVID-19 pandemic. B) Subnational = 9

Indicator 3.1.2.1: Number of government entities supported to ensure business continuity and provision of basic and social services during the COVID-19 pandemic. B) Subnational = 9
UNDP’s support to the health systems by delivering health related items at the state and regional levels will further strengthen its partnership with the local governments and help to leverage and significantly ramp up not only COVID response efforts but also ongoing programming to reach the presently hard-to-reach and conflict impacted communities through a COVID-19 early recovery programming with potential funding from the Government and other development partners. UNDP has already provided about 28,000 hygiene items (hand sanitizers, soaps, cloth masks etc) and 1260 qty of infra-red thermometers to 26 government offices and development partners. In addition, UNDP is planning to deliver 12 out of 22 types of Health related items which includes about 15,000 pieces of PPE items (goggles, surgical gowns etc in addition to other PPE items) , 8 Ventilators, 20 Oxygen Concentrators, 275 Pulse oximeters, 5 suction machines, 5 portable X-rays machines and 45,000 surgical masks for 9 S/R Governments.

1.1 Plan for fast-track health procurement in crisis situations: Developed/in progress/not developed 1.2 100% of all requested PPE delivered within 3 months 2.1 Most vulnerable people and criteria for aid are set up: Yes/ In progress/ No 2.2 At least 700 beneficiaries from vulnerable populations received social aid 2.3 At least 10,000 people provided with community support and information

1.1. Turkmenistan’s Comprehensive Action Plan for sanitary protection of the etrap/city territory from the outbreak and spread of especially dangerous and quarantine diseases was updated with UNDP support.
1.2. Eight disinfectant skid sprayers were procured for the sanitary-epidemiological service of Turkmenistan within 3 months
2.1. Rapid scan of vulnerabilities and insecurities of vulnerable groups of the population was conducted by UNDP.
2.2. 13690 food and hygiene parcels and 40500 facemasks were procured and delivered to 7940 people from the most-affected vulnerable groups of the population (low-income families, children with special needs, people with disabilities, single mothers of many children, lone elderly people) that were identified through the rapid scan of vulnerabilities and insecurities of vulnerable groups of the population.
2.3 UNDP provided funds to support the Ministry of Health in printing 5000 information booklets on COVID-19 awareness and prevention measures that were distributed among the most-affected vulnerable groups of the population.

comment.narrative: Strengthening Libya’s health system response by equipping Libyan testing, treatment and isolation centers to ensure access and response to the COVID-19 epidemic and supporting innovative digital solutions to healthcare gaps. Assessing the socio-economic impact of the crisis and supporting a recovery strategy

UNDP responded to COVID by enhancing national and local health sector capacities. UNDP Libya recruited and placed three health experts within the Ministry of Health (MoH) and Presidential Council to support the coordination of COVID response among UN agencies, NGOs, MoH and other related line Ministries. UNDP is developing an innovative application to set up a Telemedicine system for remote diagnosis of vulnerable populations by doctors. 15,000 test kits and 5 GenX machines procured and distributed to centres
Inclusive and integrated crisis management in enhanced through a whole-of-society response to COVID-19 Gender sensitive post-COVID recovery strategy

description.narrative:
Design and delivery of rapid Socio - Economic Assessment between May and December 2020
Relevant Socio - Economic levels of measure for Papua New Guinea

comment.narrative:
No Rapid Socio - Economic Assessment conducted
No relevant Socio - Economic measures for Papua New Guinea

Output 1: Rapid Socio - Economic Assessment
Targets: Rapid Socio - Economic Assessment completed
Output 2: Innovative Protection and response measures to support recovery post COVID - 19 in place.
Targets: 3 pilot Socio - Economic levels of measures support COVID - 19 recovery

Output 1 Target: Rapid Socio - Economic Assessment completed Result: SEAI Final report submitted in August. Through the Socioeconomic Impact Assessment of COVID-19 on PNG conducted during April to August 2020, UNDP in close collaboration with DNPM established the most representative gender-disaggregated national and subnational baseline and diagnostics across all the 89 districts of the 22 provinces of PNG including the most vulnerable provinces to inform inclusive growth policy responses. The government adopted 7 of the 9 recommendations outlined by the UNDP report. Among them 3 relate to fostering good business environment and private sector growth applied by the Government. These were closely coordinated with the Department of National Planning and Monitoring (DNPM), DPLGA National Statistics Office, Department of Trade and Industry, Business Council, International Labour Organization (ILO), UNICEF, UNFPA, UNCDF.
In addition the following was also achieved: -the government used the recommendations of the report to allocate its PSIP/DSIP -the report guided the government to frame the 2020 Supplementary budget -the report guided the government to frame the 2021 budget. -ADB used it as the basis for preparing the $120 million budget support to the government -World Bank used it as the basis to conduct followup surveys -UNDP is the only development partner invited to the government’s highest policy making body (CACC) to provide policy advice or be an observer
Output 2: 3 pilot Socio - Economic levels of measures support COVID - 19 recovery Result 1: Initiation of Bougainville Socio-economic Baseline Survey which will also contribute to the Bougainville Economic and Investment Summit to be hosted in Q2, 2021. So far, there has been a survey socialization exercise conducted in December with ABG District Managers and Community Government Chairmen including the ward recorders. Result 2: Initiation discussion on SEAI 2

Output 2: Innovative Protection and response measures to support recovery post COVID - 19 in place.
Targets: 3 pilot Socio - Economic levels of measures support COVID - 19 recovery

description.narrative: Local bodies and communities capable to respond Covid-19 pandemic

comment.narrative: - National Early Recovery Cluster activated - Upgrading of 3 isolation centres - More than 1,600 households from most vulnerable and marginalized group in Dolakha and Sindhupalchowk districts have sustained their livelihoods through provision of agricultural tools and materials support. - A dedicated Helpline was setup in 1 municipality (Shailung). - Public awareness was raised on preparedness of COVID i

· By extending technical support to the federal ministry, National Early Recovery Cluster was activated and operational for effective mobilization of partners in livelihood recovery and employment initiatives. . UNDP Field Offices continue play vital role in operationalization of ER clusters in the Provinces. · Provided WASH items, hospital beds to Bharatpur and Bhimeshwor Municipality for upgrading of3 isolation centres and have treated 89 people. More than 50 contactless handwashing stations have also been installed within these municipalities. · More than 1,600 households from most vulnerable and marginalized group in Dolakha and Sindhupalchowk districts have sustained their livelihoods through provision of agricultural tools and materials support. · A dedicated Helpline was setup in 1 municipality (Shailung). IT support provided by the project in the4 municipalities are effectively tracking of returnee migrants for COVID-19 response and relief distribution to most vulnerable communities. · Outreach on risk communication through publication and dissemination of IEC materials and radio program “Jeevan Rakhsya” increased the access of vulnerable population with government service providers. · Public awareness was raised on preparedness of COVID in Bhimeshwor municipalities and Lalitpur metropolis through supported in orientation and mobilization of FCHVs, ward DMCs and women groups with IEC materials to .

comment.narrative: Indicator 3.1.2.1: Number of government entities supported to ensure business continuity and provision of basic and social services during the COVID-19 pandemic. B) Subnational = 9

Indicator 3.1.2.1: Number of government entities supported to ensure business continuity and provision of basic and social services during the COVID-19 pandemic. B) Subnational = 10
UNDP’s support to the health systems by delivering health related items at the state and regional levels will further strengthen its partnership with the local governments and help to leverage and significantly ramp up not only COVID response efforts but also ongoing programming to reach the presently hard-to-reach and conflict impacted communities through a COVID-19 early recovery programming with potential funding from the Government and other development partners.
UNDP has already provided about 28,000 hygiene items (hand sanitizers, soaps, cloth masks etc) and 1260 qty of infra-red thermometers to 26 government offices and development partners. In addition, UNDP is planning to deliver 12 out of 22 types of Health related items which includes about 15,000 pieces of PPE items (goggles, surgical gowns etc in addition to other PPE items) , 8 Ventilators, 20 Oxygen Concentrators, 275 Pulse oximeters, 5 suction machines, 5 portable X-rays machines and 45,000 surgical masks for 9 S/R Governments.

1 - New partnership launched with the Union of Myanmar Federal Chamber of Commerce (UMFCCI). This had led to the organization of a high level roundtable dialogue with UNDP bringing together government, private sector and multilateral IFIs and other ley stakeholders to develop recommendations around (a) how the private sector can play a role in the national recovery process (b) and how the government can play a role in ensuring that the measures undertaken reach the most vulnerable businesses impacted by COVID. The next round is this dialogue will focus in the agriculture and livestock sector- a sector that employs 80% of the labour force in Myanmar. UNDP has forged innovative partnership with Phandeeyar to launched an initiative to crowdsource health information, based on self-reporting, to serve as an early warning system to help policy makers prioritize resource and response. UNDP is also working with the Directorate of Industrial supervision to launch a digital transformation challenge focusing on MSMEs. Discussions around other private sector collaboration in tacking COVID response and recovery is also underway.

description.narrative: 1. # of poor people/households received cash transfer to meet their food crisis/ daily needs during COVID 19 outbreaks 2. # of poor people/households received food baskets to meet their food crisis during COVID 19 outbreaks 3. # of district level SFLP members and other stakeholders received PPE/ preventive materials 4. # of local level administrative offices received thermal scanner (infrared thermometer) 5. # of local level administrative offices received megaphone (hand mike)

UNDP collaborated closely with Ministry of Home Affairs (MoHA), Ministry of Health (MoH) and WHO to implement 3 of 4 planned Provincial Level Workshops on Government Strengthening to Respond to Covid-19. The purpose of the workshops was to support 6 District and 4 Provincial level governments with preparations to respond to potential COVID-19 transmission in the country through enhanced public services and community engagement. Primary Health Care (PHC) strengthening solutions beyond COVID-19 preparedness was also an output of the workshop.

description.narrative: National and Provincial Disaster Management offices are supported to maintain coordination at all levels during preparedness, response and recovery.

sector.narrative: Accelerate structural transformations

description.narrative: Coordination of NDOC sector committees maintained Number of joint activities. NERT is equipped for deployment.

comment.narrative: 50% reduction in financial resource. Reduced staff ceiling by 4 members

- NDMO is well resourced to support coordination of multisectoral intervention at the national and provincial level. - Development of NDMO Corporate Plan - National Emergency Response Team's (NERT) curriculum integrated into Solomon Islands National University's (SINU) curriculum. - Capacity of NDMO Provincial Disaster Management Offices are increased with improved equipment, supplies and facilities.

- Number of multisectoral meetings NDMO Coordinated in year 2020 - Launching of the NDMO Corporate Plan - Launching of the NERT curriculum with SINU - Official opening of Gizo Provincial Disaster Management Office renovation, and handover of equipment (i.e. vehicle and supplies) and boats to NDMO provincial offices. - Impact of disasters on communities and institutions are minimized through implementation of well coordinated disaster response and recovery.
Additional ICT equipment and personnel Regular coordination fora Additional surge capacity available
Impact of disasters on communities and institutions are minimized through implementation of well coordinated disaster response and recovery.
